entry.title: “Our artists and creative community are the lifeblood of...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Our artists and creative community are the lifeblood of Colorado and part of why I’m so proud to call this State home,” said Representative Leslie Herod. “This program helps Colorado’s creative sector endure while preserving our vibrant reputation as a great place to live, visit, and do business. I’m grateful to my colleagues Senators Winter and Priola and Representative Sandridge for championing this important cause with me.”

EIN Presswire

December 15, 2020 | Press Releases DENVER — The Colorado Office of Economic Development and International Trade (OEDIT) today announced it is accepting

einnews.com

Applications for Colorado’s $7.5M Arts Relief Program for Individuals, Business and Organizations Now Open

entry.title: "Enrollment in Colorado public schools dropped by close to...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Enrollment in Colorado public schools dropped by close to 30,000 students this school year — the first year-to-year decrease the state’s public school system has reported in more than 30 years.

Impacts of the pandemic drove enrollment numbers down, according to the Colorado Department of Education, which released preliminary enrollment figures on Tuesday morning after counting students in October."

The Colorado Sun

Public schools reported a decrease in the number of students for the first time in 30 years, many of them in early grades.

coloradosun.com

Colorado’s public school enrollment has dropped by 30,000 students. That could spell financial disaster for districts.

Public schools reported a decrease in the number of students for the first time in 30 years, many of them in early grades.Public schools reported a decrease in the number of students for the first time in 30 years, many of them in early grades.

entry.title: “To a lot of people, even people who’ve been here their...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“To a lot of people, even people who’ve been here their whole lives, he’s just a name on a street,” Cahill said.

Not just a street. In 2008, Bruce Randolph School, for grades 6-12, opened in the neighboring Clayton neighborhood.

“Here’s a man with a third-grade education. And he’s got a school named after him,” Wooding said.

...

Cahill said he learned about the persistence of hunger in Denver through his work on the documentary, which included filming at the Thanksgiving events. Cahill has started donating to ensure Epworth can keep feeding the hungry.

Randolph “wouldn’t have been successful without help from others,” Cahill said. “That’s what drove him to start his tradition” of feeding the needy."

Denverite

See MoreBruce Randolph, the late restaurateur and philanthropist, still inspires acts of serviceHis is not just a name on a street sign.Bruce Randolph, the late restaurateur and philanthropist, still inspires acts of serviceHis is not just a name on a street sign.See more at DENVERITE.COM

entry.title: “Health care workers will be the first recipients of...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Health care workers will be the first recipients of Colorado’s first batch of vaccines, totaling 46,800 doses. The additional doses are all expected to arrive this week, with more deliveries on Tuesday and Wednesday.

The vaccine must be administered in two doses over within a three-week period to be most effective, meaning the first shipment will only be enough to inoculate 23,400 people. “

The Colorado Sun

Health care workers will be the first recipients of Colorado’s first batch of vaccines, totaling 46,800 doses and expected to arrive this week

coloradosun.com

“Absolutely historic”: First doses of Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine arrive in Colorado, are administered

Health care workers will be the first recipients of Colorado’s first batch of vaccines, totaling 46,800 doses and expected to arrive this weekHealth care workers will be the first recipients of Colorado’s first batch of vaccines, totaling 46,800 doses and expected to arrive this week

entry.title: "In a class action suit, people experiencing homelessness...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"In a class action suit, people experiencing homelessness and the advocacy group Denver Homeless Out Loud are asking federal Judge William Martinez to order the city to stop cleanups, citing guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in arguing that clearing encampments can increase the risk of spreading disease during the pandemic by causing “people to disperse throughout the community and break connections with service providers.”

In court papers filed in response to the suit, the city says any “total prohibition on cleanings and public health area restrictions … will unquestionably lead to deteriorating health and safety conditions that may be irreparable when they cannot be addressed by Denver’s consistent and measured approach.”

Denverite

Another cleanup is scheduled at the same corner where the city has authorized a nonprofit to set up and manage a temporary camp for people experiencing homelessness.

denverite.com

A cleanup is scheduled this week, as is a hearing in a court case against such operations

Another cleanup is scheduled at the same corner where the city has authorized a nonprofit to set up and manage a temporary camp for people experiencing homelessness.Another cleanup is scheduled at the same corner where the city has authorized a nonprofit to set up and manage a temporary camp for people experiencing homelessness.

entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“D-Day was a pivotal turning point in World War II. It was the beginning of the end — and that's where we are today," Gen. Gustave Perna said.

"D-Day was a pivotal turning point in World War II. It was the beginning of the end — and that's where we are today," Gen. Gustave Perna said.

nbcnews.com

ICU nurse in New York among first in country to receive Covid vaccination

entry.title: “This is a triumph of modern science,” he said. “When you...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“This is a triumph of modern science,” he said. “When you think about how long it took to get prior vaccines like polio and others to market, years, even decades, some of them, this was one was done in record time.”

The state’s distribution plans calls for the doses to first be administered to frontline healthcare workers and people living in long-term care facilities. Polis said they would be administered on Monday. Colorado will get a total of 46,800 doses this week and will receive an estimated 96,000 doses of the Moderna vaccine, which has yet to be approved, next week.”

Denverite

The state got its first shipment of the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine on Monday.

denverite.com

The first few doses of a COVID-19 vaccine are in Denver. Here’s what we know.

The state got its first shipment of the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine on Monday.The state got its first shipment of the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine on Monday.

entry.title: “But thanks to a few local leaders and many contributions,...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“But thanks to a few local leaders and many contributions, several deserving servers will receive generous tips this week – a few already have.”

As dine-in restrictions get tougher, so does the possibility of making tips for a lot of servers. That's why a few local leaders joined the tip a server challenge.

9news.com

'Tip a server' challenge raises thousands for restaurant workers in Denver

As dine-in restrictions get tougher, so does the possibility of making tips for a lot of servers. That's why a few local leaders joined the tip a server challenge.As dine-in restrictions get tougher, so does the possibility of making tips for a lot of servers. entry.title: “You could just see the desperation,” he said. “You could...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“You could just see the desperation,” he said. “You could see the heartache in their posts, the struggle — from the basic level of just trying to get somebody to pick up a phone and answer their question all the way to, ‘Hey I’m losing my house and my kids are starving and we’re going to be sleeping in the car.’”

Colorado Public Radio

Forums and online groups have sprung up during the pandemic as the unemployed search for answers they’re not getting from the state Labor Department.

coloradosun.com

Colorado’s unemployment system is so overwhelmed that strangers have resorted to helping each other

Forums and online groups have sprung up during the pandemic as the unemployed search for answers they’re not getting from the state Labor Department.Forums and online groups have sprung up during the pandemic as the unemployed search for answers they’re not getting from the state Labor Department.

entry.title: “Independent Monitor Nick Mitchell’s report, released...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Independent Monitor Nick Mitchell’s report, released Monday, found that the Denver Police Department was unprepared and acted dangerously during this summer’s protests sparked by the killing of George Floyd. Many officers acted anonymously — records of their work do not exist — and failed to activate their body cameras, obscuring who is accountable for misconduct like unnecessary violence against the public.”

Denverite

Pazen will appear before city council later this month.

denverite.com

City council, reformers weigh in on ‘chilling’ report after Chief Pazen commits to changing how police control crowds

Pazen will appear before city council later this month.Pazen will appear before city council later this month.

entry.title: “The school is home to about 50 Native American students and...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“The school is home to about 50 Native American students and has a Native American club that Morman said does things like organize an Indigenous People’s Day assembly. Rose McGuire, the Senior Manager of DPS’s Native American Culture and Education Department, and Morman said most Native American students in DPS belong to the Navajo, Lakota, and Southern Cheyenne tribes, the latter of which is based in Oklahoma. The school also has a Lakota language class. Morman helps supervise those students in addition to hosting a class for Native American students; it counts about 13 students.”

Denverite

The district has about 1,000 Native American students, the majority of whom come from Navajo Nation and nations in the Dakotas.

denverite.com

Native American students in Denver are struggling more than their peers. One program, at North High, is trying to help.

The district has about 1,000 Native American students, the majority of whom come from Navajo Nation and nations in the Dakotas.The district has about 1,000 Native American students, the majority of whom come from Navajo Nation and nations in the Dakotas.

entry.title: “Gov. Jared Polis warned Friday that even with thousands of...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Gov. Jared Polis warned Friday that even with thousands of doses of the first COVID-19 vaccine just days away from Colorado, masks and distancing will remain the best way to control the virus for months to come.”

Colorado Public Radio

The governor spoke Friday as the state released a list of hospitals that will be getting the first doses of a vaccine manufactured by Pfizer.

cpr.org

With Vaccines On the Way, Polis Warns Colorado To Be ‘Very, Very Careful This Christmas’

The governor spoke Friday as the state released a list of hospitals that will be getting the first doses of a vaccine manufactured by Pfizer.The governor spoke Friday as the state released a list of hospitals that will be getting the first doses of a vaccine manufactured by Pfizer.

entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“She said that all funds received through Sunday will to go an unsuspecting server for the holidays. Herod has already raised several hundred dollars. She said that she wants to show that anyone can do this and hopes others will get involved.”

CBS4 Local

State Rep. Leslie Herod is joining the Tip-A-Server Challenge to help those who are struggling during the coronavirus Level Red restrictions.

entry.title: “As families settle into the holiday season, the Colorado...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“As families settle into the holiday season, the Colorado Department of Health and Environment has announced a new slate of free, community-run testing sites for COVID-19.

CDPHE said in a press release that some of the new locations were already up and running as of Thursday, though some will not open until Sunday morning.”

Colorado Public Radio

CDPHE said in a press release that some of the new locations were already up and running, though some will not open until Sunday morning.

cpr.org

Free COVID Testing Sites Opening In Colorado In These Locations

entry.title: "A distribution plan unveiled Wednesday by the Colorado...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"A distribution plan unveiled Wednesday by the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment prioritizes health care workers, namely those who interact with COVID-19 patients, and nursing home residents and staff for the first doses of vaccine in what’s being referred to as “Phase 1A.”

The Colorado Sun

A distribution plan unveiled Wednesday by the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment prioritizes health care workers, and nursing home residents and staff for the first doses

coloradosun.com

General public in Colorado likely won’t have access to coronavirus vaccine until summer 2021

entry.title: "Dougherty said the dynamics pitting worker safety against...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Dougherty said the dynamics pitting worker safety against their ability to pay their bills isn’t new. It’s just been brought to the fore, like so many other societal disparities.

“The stakes are higher with COVID,” he said.

And while he’s quick to say there are plenty of employers doing the “right thing,” he hopes the state will take action while there’s still a need for oversight.

...

“We think they can and need to do better,” he said. “There’s still time to take action and save lives.”

Denverite

They’ve gotten 1,000 responses, mostly from the metro.Advocates want a hotline for Colorado employees to report COVID-19 concerns at workUnion organizers crated a complaint portal in the spring. They’ve gotten 1,000 responses, mostly from the metro.See more at DENVERITE.COM

entry.title: "On Wednesday, the Tattered Cover announced it had changed...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"On Wednesday, the Tattered Cover announced it had changed hands. Len Vlahos and Kristen Gilligan sold the 49-year-old independent bookstore to Bended Page LLC. Billed as “national bookselling and publishing experts,” Bended Page is owned by Denver natives (and former high school debate rivals) Kwame Spearman and David Back.

The famously independent bookstore’s new owners said they remember visiting the Tattered Cover as kids. Spearman, Back and Vlahos spoke to Denverite shortly after news of the sale broke to discuss the future, the past and why the Tattered Cover is now the largest Black-owned bookstore in the U.S."

Denverite

Tattered Cover is now the largest Black-owned bookstore in the country. Here’s what its new owners have to say about the store’s future.We asked the new owners how they will — and won’t — change the bookstore.Tattered Cover is now the largest Black-owned bookstore in the country. Here’s what its new owners have to say about the store’s future.We asked the new owners how they will — and won’t — change the bookstore.See more at DENVERITE.COM

entry.title: "Creatives are the lifeblood of Colorado, right? I think...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Creatives are the lifeblood of Colorado, right? I think it's what makes me so proud to be a Coloradan and what makes so many folks so proud to say that Colorado is their home. It's such an amazing creative sector.

In fact, Colorado is the number one state for audience participation and visits to our cultural facilities. That's amazing. But because of COVID-19, they've been shut down and unable to operate.

That's not just the theater, for instance. That's also the sound engi...neer, the lighting guy or gal, right? It's the DJs. It’s all of those folks who are not working right now and are not able to access a lot of resources that have come down for COVID relief. How are they going to be able to also make it through this? That is why they're included in this bill. - Rep. Leslie Herod."

9NEWS (KUSA)

See MoreMillions of COVID relief dollars will soon be available to artists, entertainers, art venues and minority-owned businesses in the state.

COVID-19 relief funds coming to Colorado's minority-owned businesses, art community, entertainers

entry.title: Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have community support for this work. We all have a story to tell. Our stories are our strength and our voices will be heard.

"Forget political stereotypes: This history-making legislator is unapologetically progressive, is insistent that state government can be bipartisan (even now), and wants to transform the criminal justice system. And that's just the start of her ambitions.”
